context: Winston Churchill (paraphrased) - If ever you are in need of good leadership, pray that Shackleton is your leader.
OK, I'll bite. Why? It's not like there is any mystery here.

replies.context:
Because it's part of an amazing story of human spirit and perseverance: read
 Spirit of Endurance: The True Story of the Shackleton Expedition to the Antarctic
Awesome telling of a great survival.

context:
Ah, for just one time I would take the Northwest Passage To find the hand of Franklin Reaching for the Beaufort Sea Tracing one warm line Through a land so wild and savage And make a Northwest Passage to the sea
Westward from the Davis Strait 'Tis there 'twas said to lie The sea route to the Orient For which so many died Seeking gold and glory, Leaving weathered, broken bones And a long-forgotten lonely cairn of stones
Three centuries thereafter I take passage overland In the footsteps of brave Kelso Where his "sea of flowers" began Watching cities rise before me Then behind me sink again This tardiest explorer Driving hard across the plain
And through the night, behind the wheel The mileage clicking west I think upon Mackenzie, David Thompson and the rest Who cracked the mountain ramparts And did show a path for me To race the roaring Fraser to the sea
How then am I so different From the first men through this way? Like them, I left a settled life I threw it all away To seek a Northwest Passage At the call of many men
To find there but the road back home again
Ah, for just one time I would take the Northwest Passage To find the hand of Franklin Reaching for the Beaufort Sea Tracing one warm line Through a land so wild and savage And make a Northwest Passage to the sea.

replies.context: A great song by the great Stan Rogers. I love his music.

context: When they find her she'll be bits and pieces, the sad remains of a once graceful vessel laying in the cold dark depths...
all this money being spent, and what's the point?

replies.context: If you must ask, you probably wouldn't understand.

context: One of the most amazing stories Iâ€™ve ever read.

Endurance was the first book I remember reading, in earnest, from cover to cover as a boy.  It sits on my bookshelf to this day.  As far a why would they be looking for the crumbled remains?  Men & women with big & wonderful toys.  Who wouldn't be interested?  I also suspect that developing tech. is being used to explore the depths in our never ending fascination with our past.  No doubt there is a number of data collecting studies happening.  Beam me up Scottie.

Shackleton and crew, what an adventure! How tough these guys were. Rowing miles upon miles in an open boat with just the  water soaked coats, in raging frozen seas. Then hiking over a tall mountain to reach the only other humans for hundreds of miles in the same old boots and frozen garments, hoping to be rescued by whalers on a tiny island. Do they make them like that anymore?

replies.context: Yup they are called Navy Seals.

context: Wait, I thought there wasn't any more ice down there.
Neat photo.  It almost looks like a negative, but you know the ice is white . .

Ya, so they have now found this ship and it wasn't totaiiy crushed/destroyed and appears to be in remarkable condition upright on the bottom.  I'd like to know how hard it would be to raise it - other than the extreme depth, it does not look like it would be difficult.

Just a thought. Expedition spokesman states the expedition, equipped with steel hulled ice breakers may or may be able to reach the point a wooden19th century was able to reach over a 100 years ago because of......pack ice. I understand such ice moves about. 
But all we hear about is how Antarctic ice is disappearing??????
